ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learning to read, write, speak in Portuguese. About culture, memory, vitality, inequality patrimony. One of the best language department for sure.
I learned lots more Portuguese that added on very well to what I learned in L1 last semester!

I developed my reading, speaking and writing skills in Portuguese. Moreover, the topics were insightful and educational about culture, choice and freedom of expression. I learned a lot on those subjects too.
vocabulary, writing, and oral skills in Portuguese as an extension on PORT 110
- improved my comfortability of speaking portuguese

Learned about Portuguese language and culture: a study of homemaking labor dynamics, afro-Brazilian culture and history, and food throughout the country. This course interacts with Portuguese and Brazilian society beyond a grammar lesson that you'd find in textbooks.
I improved my Portuguese by learning how to communicate complex societal ideas by learning how to analyze contemporary Brazilian media such as animated short films and short stories.
This course took my Portuguese speaking skills to the next level. It was highly based in talking with others, working on group projects, and learning grammar through conversation topics.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Class could work more on instruction outside the written medium. While I am comfortable reading in the is language, it would serve better if people felt comfortable with engaging with material outside the setting of school.

Strengths: very manageable workload, engaging and fun content

Weaknesses: sometimes other students were not super engaged, many people showed up late and class ended late; overall NO complaints that matter that much;  great course!

Strengths: instructor was amazing and made classes very engaging.

Weakness: I wish we could have done a bit more grammar to clarify some small but important distinctions.
There are lots of creative projects and it's very easy to ask questions and get help when you don't understand an assignment or concept.

- Giseli asks for a lot of homework to be done
- very understanding teacher
- I wish we would have started with more team-building exercises before diving into more individualistic ones rather than the other way around.
- There should be a class-facilitated vocabulary list (online somewhere) where students write down important ones used in class
- very good feedback on each piece of homework (incredible, the amount of work Giseli put in here!)
- I think we should read a more advanced book together

This course interacts with Portuguese language and Brazilian culture beyond what grammar textbooks can teach. It pushes students to evaluate their own places in cities and heritage and apply the language to express their thoughts in new forms.

The course material is very engaging and interesting, covering a wide range of art forms such as short stories, animated short films and music. Professor Tordin is a very patient and understanding professor with a passion for teaching us about the Brazilian culture.

Strengths: fast-paced class, lots of interpersonal activities, thorough feedback on assignments, caring professor, interesting assignments

Weaknesses: occasional high workload on asynchronous days, writing assignments outside of asynchronous days could take considerable time, group assignments could sometimes lead to some students taking on more work than others.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: DEFINITELY
100 percent I would. It is fun, easy, and you get what you put into it!
Definitely. A great way to learn Portuguese in an inviting and engaging environment.
Yes, Portuguese is such a fun language to take at Yale- and the professors like Giseli are amazing!

- Yes. Every language course is so valuable. Many college students do not understand that they will acquire many skills on the go and lose them if they don't use them, but languages will never come by themselves and will play a role in your life forever once you have them.

Also, why Portuguese? It's more than Brazil and Portugal. There is Angola, Mosambique, Cape Verde, East Timur, Guinea-Bissau, Macau, Sao Tome and Principe!  Some pretty cool places there!
Absolutely! Professor Tordin really cares about creating a unique and interactive language learning experience. This is a wonderful department that excels at creating a holistic learning environment

I would highly recommend this course to any student that is interested in learning more deeply about Brazilian media and art forms such as marionette puppet shows and contemporary themes such as childhood.

I would certainly recommend the course to people genuinely seeking to learn Portuguese. If someone is considering it just for a language credit (because they have experience with Spanish), I would warn that there is a lot of in-person speaking that demands your attention.
